target_geog_level: All countries

description:
"Extends automatic stay for foreigners stranded due to COVID-19. 

Foreigners who entered Viet Nam from March 1 can have their temporary stay permits automatically extended for another month until September 30, the Viet Nam Immigration Department announced on September 1.

It is another one-month extension to the current policy, issued in mid-May and extended twice since, to support foreigners stuck in the country due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The move means from now until September 30, people who came to Viet Nam under visa waiver programs, e-visas or tourism visas from March 1 can stay or leave Viet Nam without doing any paperwork or paying any fees.

Regulations on those who entered the country before March 1 remain the same as the current policy. They can be considered for this permit extension as long as they can prove they are stranded in Viet Nam due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
 
They need to provide certificates issued by their diplomatic mission in Viet Nam through an official diplomatic note with a translation in Vietnamese or documents issued by Vietnamese authorities to confirm they were quarantined or treated for COVID-19, among other reasons beyond their control.

Those who do not fall under these categories or have committed illegal actions have to abide by the existing laws on immigration./."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description: As of 28 October 2020, the Vietnamese government continues to suspend entry into Vietnam to all foreigners, including people with a Vietnamese visa exemption certificate.  This policy has very limited exemptions for diplomatic, official duty, and special cases, including experts, business managers, foreign investors, and high-tech workers of businesses involved in important projects as determined by the Government of Vietnam. Family reunification is not one of the exemptions. Individuals in these categories will have to present a certificate of negative COVID-19 RT-PCR testing report issued within the three days prior to departure.  After landing, a follow-up RT-PCR test will be conducted. All entrants into Vietnam will be placed under medical surveillance for at least 28 days.

description: On January 5, 2021, Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc has just signed Directive No. 01/CT-TTg on strengthening the prevention and control of the COVID-19 epidemic. The Ministry of National Defense will lead and coordinate with other authorities to enhance border management and prevent illegal entry through various routes, including trails and sea entrances. They will ensure strict isolation measures for people entering the country, with a concentrated 14-day quarantine and medical monitoring to prevent the spread of diseases within isolation areas and to the community. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will oversee the review of cases of overseas citizens wishing to return home, prioritizing certain individuals such as elderly people, those in difficult circumstances, and those with expired visas or contracts. They will also temporarily suspend flights from countries with new strains of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and complex epidemics, starting with the UK and South Africa.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: In the week from 11-15 January 2021, due to the emergence of a new strain of the COVID-19 virus that spreads more quickly in many countries, the Prime Minister of the Republic of Vietnam directed that until the Lunar New Year, in case it is really necessary, each flight to pick up people back home must be carried out by the ministries: Healthcare, Foreign Affairs, National Defense, Public Security, and Transport. The ministries shall uniformly report to the Prime Minister for consideration and decision.

description: As of 22 January 2021, the Vietnamese government continues to suspend entry into Vietnam to all foreigners, including people with a Vietnamese visa exemption certificate.  This policy has very limited exemptions for diplomatic, official duty, and special cases, including experts, business managers, foreign investors, and high-tech workers of businesses involved in important projects as determined by the Government of Vietnam.  Family reunification is not one of the exemptions. All entrants into Vietnam will be placed under medical surveillance for at least 28 days. All passengers using public means of transport (bus, taxi, trains, planes, ships, etc.) must complete online health declaration before the trip and minimize communications during the trip.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Starting from 28 January 2021, Quang Ninh suspends public transportation following latest Covid-19 outbreaks. The move came after the health ministry confirmed 84 community transmissions after 55 clean days, including 11 employees at Van Don International Airport. Van Don International Airport has received hundreds of repatriation flights from abroad since the government imposed travel restrictions in March last year. Chairing an urgent government meeting, Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc called on Hai Duong and Quang Ninh to swiftly track down everyone who came into contact with the clusters and temporarily close their borders to prevent the virus from spreading.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Van Don International Airport will reopen from March 3 (2021) as the pandemic in the northern province of Quang Ninh is rolled back. The airport plans to reopen routes connecting Van Don and Ho Chi Minh City and accept repatriation flights bringing in Vietnamese citizens and foreign specialists. Vietnam Airlines, the national flag carriers, will conduct the first flight on Wednesday on the Van Don-Ho Chi Minh City routes from March 3 to 7 and then increase number of weekly flights to three to be operated on Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays from March 18 to December 31.

description: It was announced on 31 March that Vietnam Airlines will reopen international commercial flights connecting Hanoi and HCMC with several Asian destinations including South Korea, Japan and Australia, starting April 3, 2021. A representative of the carrier said the resumption of these international routes are meant to meet growing travel demand of Vietnamese citizens wishing to study and work abroad as well as stranded foreigners longing to return home. On return trips, the carrier would only carry Vietnamese citizens being repatriated or foreign experts with permission to enter the country. Vietnam is yet to open its doors to foreign tourists.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The international airport of Vietnam's capital will suspend inbound flights from abroad beginning Tuesday, June 1, until June 7, the country's aviation body announced, as it grapples with a fresh wave of coronavirus outbreaks. Outbound international flights will continue, but the statement did not specify if domestic flights would be part of Noi Bai's suspension.The announcement for Hanoi's airport comes days after Ho Chi Minh City -- Vietnam's southern business hub -- issued a similar halt on foreign arrivals to its Tan Son Nhat International Airport.Tan Son Nhat's suspension was meant to be lifted by June 4, but the CAAV announced Monday it would continue until June 14.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 4 August 2021, the Ministry.of Health of the Republic of Vietnam instructed that fully vaccinated arrivals to Vietnam with negative COVID-19 tests will only have to undergo seven days of centralized quarantine and another seven days for medical observation. Specifically, the reduced quarantine period – compared to previous 14 days of centralized quarantine and seven days of follow-up medical observation – is applicable to those having certified (by relevant authorities of the home country) proof of negative RT-PCR tests for SARS-CoV-2 72 hours prior to departure, having been fully vaccinated with the last dose at least 14 days but no more than 12 months before the entry time (with vaccination certificates); or in place of vaccination records, those having been infected with coronavirus (with documents proving the positive status using RT-PCR method no more than six months prior to the entry date), or proof showing they have recovered from the disease or hospital discharge or equivalent documents issued by competent authorities in the country where they have been treated.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Travel restrictions are placed on all transport coming to and from Quang Ninh province, with 12 border controls in active requiring all travelers to provide identification, travel history form and implement contact tracing via Bluezone app upon crossing. 
From Feb 16, companies and organizations must coordinate vehicles to transit workers returning to Quang Ninh Province after Tet holiday and immediately conduct health testing for them on arriving. From Feb 15, all goverment officials are banned from travel outbound for holiday and personal purposes.
Travelers coming from areas without outbreaks or social distancing/lockdown implementations must provide negative COVID-19 test result 3-7 days prior. Otherwise, they must conduct self-quarantine and self-monitor at home for 14 days before freely commute and go to work in Quang Ninh province.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From May 8, 2021, Bac Ninh government suspended all public transport from and to stations in Bac Ninh province. All interprovincial public transport, lorries, container trucks were not allowed to stop at Bac Ninh.
Traveler vehicles were restricted to under 50% capacity and completely banned in isolated areas.

description: Starting from May 20th, 2021, public passenger transportation to and from Bac Ninh and Bac Giang provinces will be suspended until further notice. The Department of Transportation has instructed all passenger transport companies and stations to cease operations in these areas, with the exception of special cases such as official duties, transportation for patients, those who have completed their quarantine period, and vehicles used for disease prevention. Fixed-route passenger transport, contract taxis, and tourist vehicles are prohibited from stopping or picking up passengers while traveling through these provinces. Passenger transport companies are required to strictly comply with COVID-19 prevention measures and maintain a list of passengers for contact tracing purposes.

description: From 8 July 2021, public passenger transport is suspended between Hanoi and 14 provinces (Hồ Chí Minh, Bình Dương, Đồng Nai, Khánh Hòa, Phú Yên, Đắk Lắk, Quảng Ngãi, Quảng Nam, Đà Nẵng, Thừa Thiên Huế, Hà Tĩnh, Nghệ An, Thanh Hóa, Hà Nam), except for contract vehicles carrying experts, workers, and employees of agencies, industrial parks, and export processing zones. Public passenger transport between Hanoi and other provinces is subject to suspension if required by the destination province and can only resume if there are no community cases for 14 consecutive days or if new announcements are made. Transport companies are required to follow strict passenger control measures and should update their plans according to the pandemic situation in each province. The regulation also prohibits vehicles from stopping or picking up passengers in areas with outbreaks.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Binh Duong,Da Nang,Dong Nai,GJak Lak,Ha Nam,Ha Tinh,Ho Chi Minh,Khanh Hoa,Nghe An,Phu Yen,Quang Nam,Quang Ngai Province,Thanh Hoa,Thua Thien-Hue

description: From 8 July 2021, public passenger transport is suspended between Hanoi and 14 provinces (Hồ Chí Minh, Bình Dương, Đồng Nai, Khánh Hòa, Phú Yên, Đắk Lắk, Quảng Ngãi, Quảng Nam, Đà Nẵng, Thừa Thiên Huế, Hà Tĩnh, Nghệ An, Thanh Hóa, Hà Nam), except for contract vehicles carrying experts, workers, and employees of agencies, industrial parks, and export processing zones. Public passenger transport between Hanoi and other provinces is subject to suspension if required by the destination province and can only resume if there are no community cases for 14 consecutive days or if new announcements are made. Transport companies are required to follow strict passenger control measures and should update their plans according to the pandemic situation in each province. The regulation also prohibits vehicles from stopping or picking up passengers in areas with outbreaks. UPDATE: The original policy was to last until July 21st, it has been updated on July 18, 2021, to extend another 14 days and expand the target provinces to 37 from 14, including 14 provinces that had already suspended transportation services. The suspension allows exceptions for contract vehicles carrying experts, officials, workers of agencies, industrial zones, and export processing zones. Resumption of operations depends on the absence of recorded COVID-19 cases in the community for 14 consecutive days or until further notice.

description: A strict lockdown has been imposed throughout Hai Duong Province effective 0001 Feb. 16 through at least March 2 2021 in response to COVID-19 activity. Under the new directive, residents of the province are required to remain inside their homes unless leaving for essential purposes, such as purchasing food or seeking medical care. Nonessential passenger transport is banned throughout the province. Authorities will allow and facilitate the movement of essential supplies. Outdoor gatherings of more than two persons are prohibited. All nonessential businesses in Hai Duong Province are closed.

description: On May 18, Vietnam’s Ministry of Public Security (MPS) announced a new policy that provides an automatic extension of temporary stay for foreigners in certain qualifying groups with plans to depart Vietnam.  U.S. citizens and other foreign nationals who entered Vietnam with a visa exemption certificate, e-visa, or tourist visa on or after March 1, 2020, will be granted an automatic extension of stay through June 30, 2020, and may exit Vietnam during this period without having to apply for an extension of stay.  U.S. citizens and other foreign nationals who entered Vietnam before March 1, 2020, may be considered for an automatic extension through June 30, 2020, provided that they can provide proof that they have been stranded in Vietnam due to COVID-19 mandatory quarantine, treatment, or other reasons beyond their control by presenting an exit letter from their Embassy or Consulate about their situation.  They must present these documents upon exiting Vietnam.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: This is the visa extension of the Vietnamese government for foreigners.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On September 22, 2020, Vietnamese Ministry of Health published guidance for international travellers. People entering Vietnam to work for more than 14 days (including foreigners holding diplomatic passports, official passports, investors, highly skilled workers, business managers, international students and foreign relatives of Vietnamese citizens) should undergo COVID-tests twice in Vietnamese quarantine centre after their arrival. If both tests are negative, they will be allowed to go home to self-isolate for 14 days. If there is a positive test result, the person will be quarantined at a medical facility and follow treatment according to the current regulations for COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 23, 2020, Can Tho's commercial centers and dining establishments have reopened with precautions. Businesses follow city guidelines, reducing seating, maintaining social distance, and providing sanitization measures. Entertainment venues remain closed. Shopping malls like Sense City Cần Thơ, Vincom Xuân Khánh, Vincom Hùng Vương, and Big C Cần Thơ have reopened, with hygiene measures and limited customer density. Traditional markets continue, with masks encouraged but not consistently adhered to. Air travel resumes, adhering to strict safety measures.

description:
Starting from April 23, 2020, Da Nang City in Vietnam is implementing a relaxation of COVID-19 related measures. People were allowed to resume business activities such as operating restaurants and cafes, while citizens were encouraged to prefer takeout. Establishments offering on-site dining must maintain a 2-meter distance between patrons and adhere to recommended health guidelines.

Cultural and sports events, as well as entertainment activities with large gatherings, remain suspended. Businesses like bars, clubs, karaoke, and massage services continue to be closed. Accommodation facilities like hotels and resorts can reopen but must follow safety regulations to prevent disease transmission.

description:
Ho Chi Minh City has eased social distancing measures but maintains the suspension of non-essential businesses to prevent COVID-19. The directive is effective from April 23, 2020, and will remain in place until further notice. Businesses are encouraged to follow stringent hygiene practices, conduct online administrative tasks, and maintain social distancing of at least 2 meters in public spaces.

Suspended business activities include beauty salons, cosmetic surgery, spas, physical therapy, massage, saunas; entertainment venues like amusement parks, theaters, cinemas, wedding halls, nightclubs, bars, karaoke, pubs, beer clubs; electronic gaming centers; indoor sports facilities. Additionally, homestay and AirBnb accommodations are required to cease accepting new guests.

Additionally, homestay and AirBnb accommodations are required to cease accepting new guests.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Ho Chi Minh City has eased social distancing measures but maintains the suspension of non-essential businesses to prevent COVID-19. The directive is effective from April 23, 2020, and will remain in place until further notice. Businesses are encouraged to follow stringent hygiene practices, conduct online administrative tasks, and maintain social distancing of at least 2 meters in public spaces.

Suspended business activities include beauty salons, cosmetic surgery, spas, physical therapy, massage, saunas; entertainment venues like amusement parks, theaters, cinemas, wedding halls, nightclubs, bars, karaoke, pubs, beer clubs; electronic gaming centers; indoor sports facilities. Additionally, homestay and AirBnb accommodations are required to cease accepting new guests.

description: On April 23, 2020, Can Tho's commercial centers and dining establishments have reopened with precautions. Businesses follow city guidelines, reducing seating, maintaining social distance, and providing sanitization measures. Entertainment venues remain closed. Shopping malls like Sense City Cần Thơ, Vincom Xuân Khánh, Vincom Hùng Vương, and Big C Cần Thơ have reopened, with hygiene measures and limited customer density. Traditional markets continue, with masks encouraged but not consistently adhered to. Air travel resumes, adhering to strict safety measures.

description:
Starting from April 23, 2020, Da Nang City in Vietnam is implementing a relaxation of COVID-19 related measures. People were allowed to resume business activities such as operating restaurants and cafes, while citizens were encouraged to prefer takeout. Establishments offering on-site dining must maintain a 2-meter distance between patrons and adhere to recommended health guidelines.

Cultural and sports events, as well as entertainment activities with large gatherings, remain suspended. Businesses like bars, clubs, karaoke, and massage services continue to be closed. Accommodation facilities like hotels and resorts can reopen but must follow safety regulations to prevent disease transmission.

description: In the context of the widespread Covid-19 epidemic in Vietnam, Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc on March 23, 2020 requested the closure of nonessential services, minimizing the gathering of people at the same time, suggest worship facilities not to gather in large numbers. UPDATE: From April 23, 2020, in Hanoi, some business activities and transportation services have been allowed to restart gradually, while following the safety guidelines prescribed by the Ministry of Health. Restaurants must ensure safe distancing among tables and provide protective barriers to prevent transmission. Shopping malls and supermarkets are required to maintain physical distancing and conduct temperature checks, along with providing hand sanitizers. Construction companies and workers are expected to take responsibility for implementing preventive measures and maintaining a logbook of schedules. The resumption of operations does not include bars, karaoke parlors, massage establishments, and electronic game centers, which are to remain closed until at least April 30, as stated in Directive 15. Additionally, large gatherings, cultural events, and sports activities are still prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 7 2020, Vietnam's PM announced that non-essential business establishments can resume operations with precautions EXCEPT for discos and karaoke parlors/services. UPDATE: The original policy requires multiple social distancing precautions, many were lifted on May 11, 2020. The PM announced the reopening of production, business, trade, and service establishments while implementing safety measures such as wearing masks and regular hand sanitization. Hand sanitization only is required at restaurants. However, karaoke parlors and nightclubs are not permitted to reopen until further instructions from the Government. UPDATE: On June 9, 2020, Vietnam's Prime Minister has approved the reopening of nightclubs and karaoke venues from June 10.

description: On July 29, 2020, Thừa Thiên – Huế province in Vietnam has announced a series of measures to combat the spread of COVID-19. description: As of Feb. 1, The People's Committee of Thủ Dầu Một City in Bình Dương Province, Vietnam, issued an urgent announcement to close non-essential businesses such as cinemas, bars, karaoke venues, massage parlors, gyms, clubs, tourist and entertainment facilities. Religious activities, events, and gatherings were also suspended. Food and beverage establishments were required to maintain distance between customers, provide sanitization, temperature check, and were limited to take-out services only, with closure by 10 PM. The Phú Hòa Ward is subjected to additional social distancing measures, and medical isolation is enforced in a specific location for infected individuals. These measures were to last until further notice.

description: As of Feb. 1, The People's Committee of Thủ Dầu Một City in Bình Dương Province, Vietnam, issued an urgent announcement to close non-essential businesses such as cinemas, bars, karaoke venues, massage parlors, gyms, clubs, tourist and entertainment facilities. Religious activities, events, and gatherings were also suspended. Food and beverage establishments were required to maintain distance between customers, provide sanitization, temperature check, and were limited to take-out services only, with closure by 10 PM. The Phú Hòa Ward is subjected to additional social distancing measures, and medical isolation is enforced in a specific location for infected individuals. These measures were to last until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: All non-essential businesses are closed during a strict lockdown throughout Hai Duong Province effective from Feb. 16 through at least March 2, 2020, announced by the provincial government. Nonessential passenger transport is banned throughout the province. Authorities will allow and facilitate the movement of essential supplies. Officials had previously imposed strict movement controls in Chi Linh from late January but expanded the measures to cover the entire province after discovering dozens of additional COVID-19 cases. Officials have set up screening checkpoints on roads throughout Hai Duong Province. Additional security personnel will likely remain deployed in the province to enforce movement and gathering restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Hanoi People's Committee announced on March 1, 2021 that restaurants and cafes allowed to reopen as of March 2. Indoor restaurants are allowed to reopen, though officials are requiring establishments to ensure 1m social distancing between patrons or use partitions between seating areas. Businesses must strictly follow COVID-19 prevention measures, including using QR codes for contact tracing. UPDATE: Hanoi authorities continue to close nightclubs and karaoke lounges while other businesses and activities have resumed, including internet and online gaming parlors as of March 16.

description: Following the announcement of People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City, starting May 31, 2021, a citywide social distancing policy was in effect. This entails temporary closure of recreational venues, beauty salons, cinemas, and dine-in restaurants. Essential services such as supermarkets, food shops, pharmacies, medical facilities, banks, and utility services (electricity, water, and telecommunications); and takeout eateries remain operational, adhering to safety protocols. Social distancing, travel history, facemasking, hand sanitization, limitations of services, disinfection are required. The social distancing measures and business restrictions in Ho Chi Minh City are initially set to be in effect until June 15, 2021. However, this end date is subject to change based on the evolving COVID-19 situation and government decisions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Prime Minister has ordered the implementation of Directive 16 in southern provinces of Vietnam from July 19, 2021, for 14 days.  Directive 16 mandates closures of non-essential businesses, restaurants, bans public gatherings, and severely limits transportation services.  The impacted provinces include HCMC, Binh Duong, Dong Nai – and the newly added – Can Tho, Binh Phuoc, Tay Ninh, Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Tien Giang, Long An, Vinh Long, Dong Thap, Ben Tre, Hau Giang, An Giang, Bac Lieu, Soc Trang, Tra Vinh, Ca Mau, and Kien Giang.

description:
The prohibitions came into force from 12:00 pm on Thursday as per a decision made by the city’s chairman.

People must keep a distance of at least two meters and not gather in groups of more than two in public. All sporting activities, including biking and walking as an exercise, and non-essential businesses have to be put to a halt. Production facilities shall arrange for workers to stay inside their premises, while shopping malls, supermarkets, and markets must apply social distancing measures. Expendable stalls inside supermarkets and markets, however, shall be suspended from operating. Workers must present related documents for their travel between their home and workplace. Also went into effect was the suspension of delivery and ride-hailing services and business cars under nine seats.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Hanoi has begun a gradual easing of economic activities from April 23 while adhering to COVID-19 safety guidelines. Eateries must ensure safe distancing with shields, malls require distancing and temperature checks, construction sites are responsible for disease prevention, and transport services are permitted at 20-30% capacity. Bars, karaoke, and entertainment venues remain closed until at least April 30. Stricter measures are applied in high-risk areas. Despite easing, mask-wearing and hygiene are emphasized.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 23, 2020, Can Tho's commercial centers and dining establishments have reopened with precautions. Businesses follow city guidelines, reducing seating, maintaining social distance, and providing sanitization measures. Entertainment venues remain closed. Shopping malls like Sense City Cần Thơ, Vincom Xuân Khánh, Vincom Hùng Vương, and Big C Cần Thơ have reopened, with hygiene measures and limited customer density. Traditional markets continue, with masks encouraged but not consistently adhered to. Air travel resumes, adhering to strict safety measures.

description:
Starting from April 23, 2020, Da Nang City in Vietnam is implementing a relaxation of COVID-19 related measures. People were allowed to resume business activities such as operating restaurants and cafes, while citizens were encouraged to prefer takeout. Establishments offering on-site dining must maintain a 2-meter distance between patrons and adhere to recommended health guidelines.

Cultural and sports events, as well as entertainment activities with large gatherings, remain suspended. Businesses like bars, clubs, karaoke, and massage services continue to be closed. Accommodation facilities like hotels and resorts can reopen but must follow safety regulations to prevent disease transmission.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 16, 2020, Vietnam's Prime Minister mandated the use of face masks in public places. This social distancing policy requires all Vietnamese nationals and foreign citizens in Vietnam to wear face masks in crowded public locations including supermarkets, airports, bus terminals, and while travelling via public transportation. UPDATE: The original mandate was announced without fines, which were updated via Decree 117/2020/NĐ-CP on September 8, 2020. Those who do not wear masks in public spaces could face a fine of up to 3 million VND.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: Quang Ninh province in Vietnam has implemented social distancing measures in specific areas from January 29 to February 21, 2021. Across the province, non-essential services such as cinemas, karaoke, pubs, massage, accommodation, tourism, restaurants, entertainment venues, sporting centers, and gaming centers are temporarily suspended. Businesses involved in the production and distribution of essential goods like food, medicine, and other essential commodities are allowed to continue operations, given the protective measures: keeping distance of 2m, no gathering of more than 2 people outside of workplaces and hospitals,

description: As of Feb. 1, The People's Committee of Thủ Dầu Một City in Bình Dương Province, Vietnam, issued an urgent announcement to close non-essential businesses such as cinemas, bars, karaoke venues, massage parlors, gyms, clubs, tourist and entertainment facilities. Religious activities, events, and gatherings were also suspended. Food and beverage establishments were required to maintain distance between customers, provide sanitization, temperature check, and were limited to take-out services only, with closure by 10 PM. The Phú Hòa Ward is subjected to additional social distancing measures, and medical isolation is enforced in a specific location for infected individuals. These measures were to last until further notice.

 UPDATE: Multiple businesses were reopened starting from March 9, 2021, including pubs, beer clubs, and sports facilities. Karaoke, nightclubs, and bars remain closed until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Following the announcement of People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City, starting May 31, 2021, a citywide social distancing policy was in effect. This entails temporary closure of recreational venues, beauty salons, cinemas, and dine-in restaurants. Essential services such as supermarkets, food shops, pharmacies, medical facilities, banks, and utility services (electricity, water, and telecommunications); and takeout eateries remain operational, adhering to safety protocols. Social distancing, travel history, facemasking, hand sanitization, limitations of services, disinfection are required. The social distancing measures and business restrictions in Ho Chi Minh City are initially set to be in effect until June 15, 2021. However, this end date is subject to change based on the evolving COVID-19 situation and government decisions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
